Situation1: Their partner faces a tough decision at work and seeks advice and encouragement.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: Roads are dry with light traffic and normal speed limits
Story: I was behind the wheel, the city lights blurring past as I drove my usual route. My phone buzzed with a message from my partner: “Can we talk? I really need you right now.” She was facing a tough decision at work, and I knew she counted on me for advice and encouragement. I wanted to pull over, call her, and be the supportive spouse she needed. But as a taxi driver, I had a passenger in the backseat, quietly checking his watch. The roads were clear, and the speed limit was normal, but I couldn’t just stop or get distracted. My job demanded my full attention—follow traffic laws, drive safely, and get my passenger to his destination on time. I felt torn, my hands gripping the steering wheel tighter. My heart ached to be there for her, but my responsibility to my passenger and the rules of the road weighed just as heavily. The pressure built inside me, each expectation pulling me in a different direction, and I found myself caught in the middle, unsure which role to honor first.
